a successful experiment. It is not being done for the purpose of helping the particular localities that have been chosen for the work. These localities have been chosen because they seem to be distinctly cheesemaking centres, where these curing establishments and the experiments carried on in them will be under the observation of those engaged in the industry. The places chosen are Woodstock, in western Ontario, Brockville in eastern Ontario; St. Hyacinthe for the French parts of the province of Quebec, and Cowansville for the English speaking parts. The general results will be published as they are learned; and if, at the end of the season those results meet

tiie expectations of those who are interested, I trust and believe that the cheesemaking centres of the country will adopt the system for themselves and carry it out in a commercial way. There is no intention on the part of the government to do this work all over the country. We shall follow the precedent set iu the case of what is called winter dairying. Under my predecessor, Professor Robertson inaugurated in Ontario and Prince Edward Island, and also, I tliiuk, in Nova Scotia, winter dairying stations, where butter was made on a considerable scale throughout the winter for the purpose of showing the butter-makers that butter could so be made as well as in summer. Certain localities were chosen because they seemed to be suitable for the experiments. So in this case. The hon. gentleman asked me how it would be worked. Without going into details, I may say generally that we are putting up a building which will be arranged so that we can control the temperature in the curing room, where the cheese will be kept. We also hope to have, in one or two of the buildings at all events, several small chambers where we can try experiments in curing cheese at different temperatures within the range that experiments in New York State and Guelph have shown to be the best. We also expect to box the cheese, and I trust and expect that our work in that respect will lead to improvement throughout the country. The boxing of our cheese, up to the present time, has not been all that we could desire. For many years the defects iu this respect have caused a serious loss annually. Arrangements will be made to bring in cheese from the factories which are to supply them to the central curing room. The cheese will be brought in immediately after it is made up in the presses-probably the next day after it is taken out of the press.
Is there no danger of deterioration ?

We propose to arrange a special kind of hoop to carry the cheese in. The cheese will be placed on the shelves in the central curing room and will then be under the control and management of the expert in charge of the building. We do not know yet exactly how long the curing process will take, but we have a pretty fair idea. When the cheese is cured and declared ready for market, it will be at the disposal of its owners, the people who supplied it. We have no control of the sale of it or of the commerce in it. The cheese may be left iu the central curing room for a short time, we do not know exactly how long. But I do not think that these central curing rooms ought to be used as a sort of keeping warehouse for the cheese. If they were kept there for a long time the accumulation of cheese would make it necessary to increase Hon. Mr. FISHER.
the size of the building and spend money iu the care of the cheese. That is a business for an ordinary warehouse properly epuipped. We are satisfied-in fact we know from our experiments-that cheese will shrink very much less In these curing rooms than in the ordinary curing rooms in the factories. And we know also, as well as we can know anything in the future, that cheese cured in these central establishments will be worth considerably more than if cured in the old rooms under varying temperatures running sometimes as high as 85 or even 90 degrees Farenlieit. We know also that cheese cured in this way can be made softer and moister, that is, the maker will be able to make more pounds of cheese to every hundred pounds of milk than under the present system of curing. Therefore, the profit in the business will be threefold; first, a given quantity of milk will make more cheese; second, the cheese will shrink less in the curing room and so will weigh out more when it comes to be sold; and, third, the price of cheese will be better than if cured under the ordinary conditions. The buildings we propose to make in a substantial manner, in a way which may, I trust, be a model in the future for the buildings put up by companies or individuals for similar purposes. In the course of the summer's work we shall probably find many details which will have to be changed from our present plan. But we believe we have outlined the plan as well as can be done without (practical experience. For this is a pure experiment from the word ' go.' I trust that at the end of the season we shall be able to make a report to the cheese-makers of Canada which will enable them to go on to do this work for themselves as successfully as they do other work in connection with this great cheese-making industry.
Is it the intention of the minister to establish a central curing house in the province of New Brunswick ?
No.
Why not ?

Because, at the present time there is no cheese-making centre in New Brunswick which would justify the expectation that an establishment of this kind could be satisfactorily worked, besides, the results gained in Ontario and Quebec, where there are great cheese-making centres, will be equally available for New Brunswick.

I think the minister is misinformed as to the facts. The county from which I have the honour to come is the pioneer of the cheese industry in New Brunswick, and is a great cheese-making centre. Within a radius of ten miles there must be twenty-five or thirty factories, some I of them with an output of 100 tons a year.

There are none of them with a smaller output than from 35 to 40 tons. 1 doubt if In any of the other provinces there is a single county with a larger cheese output than the county of King's. As the minister has taken a large vote for this purpose, I think the province of New Brunswick, although small, should not he beneath his notice, and I respectfully submit that he should establish one of these curing establishments in that county. I would like to ask him further what is the intention of the government with respect to these curing establishments after they have passed the experimental stage.
We hope to pass them over to somebody who will take them up as a commercial business, that is we intend to sell them.

I would invite the minister to examine into the output of cheese in the province of New Brunswick, and to give his serious attention to the question of putting one of these curing establishments in King's county. He might place it in St. John, there would be no difficulty there, because the cheese could come 40 or 50 miles by railway.

This last suggestion is entirely out of the question, we could not send cheese in a green condition by railway for 40 or 50 miles. It will have to be brought in by wagons constructed for that purpose. The probability is that 10 miles would be the outside limit of distance. Our present expectation is that the cheese will only be brought a distance of 5 or 6 miles into the curing establishment.
About what will be the amount of cheese gathered from the section where you are going to place this curing establishment, that is to say, the section that will be served by the establishment ?

The number of cheese that would be brought into these curing rooms will be comparatively small. A large section will not be able to send all its cheese in. It would depend upon the size of the factory. In the province of Quebec, as a general rule, the factories are not as large as they are in Ontario, and in the former province it will take more factories to provide the cheese which we propose to accommodate in these curing rooms. But I could not give the exact number of factories that would be accommodated. Our intention is to build rooms which will accommodate in the neighbourhood of 2,000 cheese a month. In Woodstock and Brockville there would be more factories within a narrow radius which could supply that number of cheese. The suggestion has been made that perhaps we should take half the number of cheese
from each factory so as to take from a larger number of factories, instead of taking the whole of the cheese from some factories and leaving out others.
What is the average cost of eacli one of these curing establishments ?
The buildings, plant and equipment will cost between $8,000 and $10,000 each.

Will the minister not make a larger establishment at some places than at others ? For instance, at Woodstock there are 2,000 cheese made a month in the three factories in the immediate neighbourhood. I would suggest that Woodstock might have a larger room than some other places where there is a smaller output. I would also ask whether the department will hold these cheese until they are cured, or will allow the owner to take them out whenever he finds a market for them. The owner might find a mariret and not be able to withdraw them when he wished. There might be a variety of opinions about the time required to cure the cheese, and the right time to market them. Buyers of cheese have methods of curing and holding their own cheese for a time.

Our expectation and intention is to hold the cheese there until they are properly cured and fit for market. In these cool chambers it will take a cheese longer to become fit for market than it does where the temperature is higher. That has been the universal experience. 1 confess that I would much regret to see the owners of cheese take them away before they were properly cured and fit for market ; but I can hardly say that I would refuse to allow an owner of cheese to take them out when ever he likes. It would be rather difficult for me to say to a man : These cheese of yours are not fit for market, and you shall not have them yet, whether you want them or not. Although I would do everything I could to persuade him to leave them there long enough to have them fit for market.
It would not be well to make a hard and fast rule, but the owner should have the option to take advantage of a favourable market.

I do not think the difficulty has arisen so much in Ontario, but I do know that in the province of Quebec, in the eastern townships, a great deal of cheese has been sold too green, allowed to leave the factories before it was really fit to be moved, and that has hurt the cheese trade. I hope we will be able to induce the factory owners and the owners of the cheese to leave their cheese long enough to ripen properly.

What would the minister think with regard to building a larger curing

room at Woodstock than at other places ? As I said, two or three factories could occupy all the capacity.
They may he built of different sizes. They are all planned in such a way that they can be easily enlarged.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I would like an explanation about this pamphlet sent out by the Department of Agriculture.
Is that a departmental publication, or is it a campaign document ?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
I will send it over to the hon. gentleman. There is a photograph of the minister in the front part of it. I understood from him that this was published in 1900.
The MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE I thought so, from what the hon. gentleman read.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Then he does not know whether he has sent out only one document or not, because he has sent out none since, as I understood him.
I do not think I have sent out anything since.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
It says :
The following is a comparison during the last four years und"r Conservative rule and the last four years under the Liberal administration.
It gives the quantity of butter exported for the years 1893, 1894, 1895 and 1S96 ; and then for the four years under Liberal administration of 1897, 1898, 1899 and 1900. I do not know how he could publish and distribute this book in 1900, when he professes to include the exports of these four articles in 1900. It could not be until after 1900 that the hon. gentleman could gather the statistics and publish them. In another table he gives a comparative statement of the expenditure under four years of Conservative administration and four years of Liberal administration, including 1901. He is trying to prove to the farmers that he is doing more for them in the expenditure of money under these heads than the Conservative government did. So this document must certainly have been sent out to the farmers since 1901, or else he is trying to impose upon them. He can take whichever horn of the dilemma he chooses. I send this pamphlet over to the hon. gentleman.
I think this is a pamphlet which was largely prepared by myself, though not altogether. It seems to have been issued in the election campaign of 1900.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: How does the hon. gentleman account for giving these tables for the full year of 1900.

When that campaign was made the shipping season from Montreal had been closed, and our butter shipments were known. They were published within a few days pf the close of that season by the Montreal papers, a synopsis is always made and given to them. We have besides that a record in our department of the amount of butter and cheese that is shipped from Montreal during the shipping season and the comparison is made with that. As far as the expenditure of the department for this season is concerned the hon. gentleman says himself that he quoted the estimated expenditure and that was included in the statement of the pamphlet and showed what my department was doing during the current year. As far as these statements are concerned I can simply say to the hon. gentleman that they went before the farmers of the country and that the farmers read them, studied them and digested them. These statements were criticised by the hon. gentlemen opposite and their candidates.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: And they succeeded in Ontario.

While they succeeded probably in Ontario they were !"ft in a small minority in the elections of 1909. In the province of Ontario there was a small majority I grant, you in their favour, b.'t Ontario is not the whole Dominion of Canada, and when the representation in this House, which has to deal with these matters, whicli has to judge these matters, has a majority, as we showed the other night of fifty-six in favour of the administration which was exposed and shown in that pamphlet, as far as my department was concerned, the result to me, at all events, is very gratifying, and I can well understand that lion, gentlemen are not so well pleased.

Do I understand the hon. Minister of Agriculture to say that the figures contained in that pamphlet were furnished by his department ?
T1'" MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE. I think probably most of them were.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Then, I will take up another branch. I understand from the hon. minister that he made several trial shipments of poultry, that they were very successful, that they brought in good prices and that it was a good business for a farmer to engage in ?
Yes. Does the hon. gentleman want the details of them ?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
No. I want to ask the farmers of the country if they could do business as the hon. gentleman has done.
I see at page D-59 of the Auditor General's report that the hon. gentleman has ex-

pended $6,580.17 in the preparation of poultry for market. I find that a gentleman by the name of A. S. McBean of Lancaster purchased a number of chickens and furnished food to them at the expense of $321.94. They were sent over to England under this system of cold storage and they brought $78.28, the experiment entailing a loss of nearly $200. I want to know how the hon. gentleman can tell the farmers of this country that this is a profitable business for them to engage in, and how he can explain this way of doing business. Altogether the department expended $6,580.17 for the preparation of poultry for market and the receipts from the sales of this poultry amounted to $1,833.45, showing a deficiency of $4,746.72 in the experimenting feeding and shipping of poultry to the old country.
At the Lancaster station ?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Lancaster was one of them. Then I see that T. L. Brant of Whitby expended $445.64 and Whitby returned $177.73. I presume that my hon. friend, wherever he made his experiments, picked out political friends to give the money to.
It would be better done probably.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
And it was probably done. Mr. Brant got $445.00 and returned $177.73. The receipts being shown in the Auditor General's report at page D-68. The Auditor General deducts the refunds for the sale of poultry, cheese, &c. This being the fact, I wonder how the hon. minister can recommend the farmers of the country to go into the feeding of poultry and shipping it to England if better results cannot be achieved.
The MINISTER OF xVGRICULTURE. If these results were such as the hon. member for South Leeds (Mr. Taylor) has stated them there is no doubt that it would not be very profitable. As a matter of fact, the expenditure which the hon. gentleman fctatcd as the expanse on these particular lots of chickens included the establishment of the stations, and the experimental and educational work which these men were carrying on. Prof. Robertson gave the details in connection with these shipments every year before the Agriculture Committee of the House and they are published in the annual report of the department and these details show that the price of these chickens in England is about double the cost that is incurred here. As a matter of fact a number of men whom we started in this work and who at first did experimental work, such as Mr. Brant and Mr. McBean are doing to-day, are doing this work themselves now. They have left the work of the department and are no longer
doing it but have entered into business on a commercial basis and are making it pay. The results are also evident from the fact that in 1896, before this work commenced, our whole export of chicken meat to Great Britain was about $18,000 and that during this last session it amounted to $220,000. To-day our chicken exporters say that they will take all the fatted chickens they can get and pay ten cents a pound for them in the centres where they are working. They are sending them forward and making a profit on them and they are doing this business on a large scale.
They want these chickens fattened. They do not fatten the chickens themselves.

No, they want them fattened and the price seems remunerative to those who fatten them and they make a profit in sending them forward. The result is, that from England we have had over and over again reports showing that the Canadian fattened chickens which arrived there have made a good reputation for themselves in the markets anu that the people there will take just as many of ikem as we can send.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: The hon. gentleman informs the House and the country that the amount of money 1 stated had been expended was for building the stations at these different points.
For establishing them.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)

speechtext: I have just received a memorandum from Professor Robertson which says that as far as the Lancaster station is concerned the chickens were taken with a disease and that was the only station which that occurred. At the Whitby station the expenditures were as I have stated. At Lancaster there was an epidemic of which most of the chickens died.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Is it not a fact that they spoiled in cold storage ?
No. They did not go to England at all.
I think I heard it stated that Canadian birds had been fattened too much, and that they were to some extent unsaleable, because when they were sent to England they were found to be too large.

There is a fancy market in England which takes a large bird and pays an extra price for it, and there is another market which prefers a smaller bird. Some of those dealers who wanted smaller birds complained that the birds we sent them were too large, and consequently we sent the large birds to the market which required such and which pays a larger price per pound.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I find here that Mr. Horace Hazard of the Charlottetown poultry station spent $499, received $94, and had a deficit of $405. What became of that $405 ?

I have not the details, but I can tell the hon. gentleman that the chickens sold at a good profit on the cost of the actual chickens purchased to fatten. At each of these stations we have got to do installation and educational and experimental work, which . cannot be charged in a commercial sense against the chickens. We have kept a strict account of the cost of the production of every shipment made this year, and it shows a large margin on the profit side. Last fall, on all the shipments that were made, we netted 13 cents a pound at Montreal, and to any one who has raised chickens it will be evident that there is a large profit at such a price.

It strikes me that the Minister of Agriculture in his chicken experiment has had a somewhat similar experience to that Horace Greeley had with his pig. That may be occasioned by the class of men to whom he entrusted the working out of this experiment. There was a chicken fattening station in my county at Sussex, and without knowing whether the results were successful or otherwise, I can say that the gentleman who managed it had no experience whatever in that line.
Was hs a lawyer V Mr. TAYLOR.
No; he did not have the training that a lawyer would have. He was a sort of an agent who sold carriages and agricultural implements. I would like to know if he was successful in his operations ?
I am informed that he was.
I am glad to know that.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext:
I can tell my hon. friend how successful he was.
Mi-. FOWLER. Perhaps it is as well, because the minister has a peculiar idea about success.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Well, Mr. McArthur charged $297 to fatten the chickens, and he sold them at $198, leaving $99 of a. deficit.
That was very successful.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: There was another station at Alberton, in Prince Edward Island, where the expenses were $249, and the receipts $154, leaving a deficit of about $100. Mr. Matthews was in charge of that station, and my hon. friend (Mr. Hackett) can tell whether he is a professional or not.
So far as the chicken business is concerned, the Minister of Agriculture had better fly the coop.

I hope the minister will give me the information now, which I asked from him the other day as regards the sale of chickens from the Alberton station. The hon. member for Leeds (Mr. Taylor) referred to Mr. Horace Hazard, of Charlottetown. I can say that Mr. Horace Hazard knows nothing whatever about fattening chickens.. He is a commission merchant in Charlottetown, and I do not know how his name got mixed up with fattening chickens, because I think he could repudiate the idea that he is a chicken fattener. lie does a large business in Prince Edward Island; he is one of the largest exporters in the province and he is not in the chicken fattening line at all. If the hon. gentleman from West Queen's (Mr. Farquliarson) were in his seat, he would remember that Mr. Hazard was going to be his opponent at the last election, and now we find that Mr. Hazard is in some way brought in connection with fattening chickens.
He is a kind of political rooster,

Mr. Hazard having made this amount of money out of fattening chickens with the least possible difficulty, he was able to retire to make way for the member for West Queen's. If Mr. Hazard had not that fattening chicken job, he would certainly have contested the election against the hon. member (Mr. Farquharson). But the gentlemen who now occupy the

Treasury benches always seem to be able to provide a solace for any of their friehds who get out of humour. Joking apart, it may be possible that the fattening industry would become of some importance as a by product of the farm in the province of Prince Edward Island. Mr. Gilbert, from the Experimental Farm, was in the Island last year, and he really did some very practical work, and by his addresses to the farmers he showed them, I think, that they might increase their revenue by poultry raising. I want to have it understood, however, that as a government proposition It has been a complete failure in the province of Prince Edward Island. Mr. Gilbert or a gentleman like him who so- thoroughly understands the chicken business can do a great deal of good by explaining to the farmers how to raise these chickens, the best breeds to raise, and how to place them on the market in the best shape.
The government stations are for experimenting and we give the results of the experiments to the farmers.
Very encouraging.

It is so encouraging that in Summerside the man who did our work gave it up, and has ever since been doing business for himself, and making money hand over fist at that business. The same is true in several other instances throughout the country. Had the government not undertaken this work, that business would not in all probability have been done in Canada for many years later than it has been. The result of our work has been that a very large number of people are engaged in this business with profit to themselves and to the country. As far as Mr. Hazard is concerned, it was two years ago when he did this work for us and consequently that could'not have influenced him very much in the election that tcok place a few months ago.

With reference to the station at Glengarry, I may say a few words, as I am somewhat conversant with the circumstances. For some time the government had been issuing bulletins advising the farmers to take up the fattening of chickens as a profitable by-product, and adjunct of their general farming business. But those who had tried it up to the time the government started these experimental stations, did not seem to have made a success of it. When the station was started at Lancaster, an official came down from the Experimental Farm, and he showed us how to do the work. He showed the young men how to go through the mixing and feeding and the methods of taking care of the chickens, and the result has been that dozens of people have taken this up as a part of their business in the county of Glengarry, and have found it very profitable. I could give a number of names of prominent men who have taken the business up in connection with their farming. For instance, there is Mr. Macdonald, in the village of Glengarry, who has fitted up for this purpose a part of his stables, which he had been using for fattening cattle. And he told me a short time ago that he intended using another stable for chicken fattening, and drop the feeding of cattle' as a business to that extent. My own brother shipped last year thirty tons of chickens partly fed and partly bought.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: That has been going on for the past fifty years.

No, it has not. These parties never shipped any before these stations were instituted. I do not think it is fair to expect that the government must make profit out of every experiment they undertake. They are expected to carry on these experiments to find out whether a certain thing may be profitable or not. AVhen they discovered it is not profitable, they are conferring a benefit by pointing that out to the people. The result of these chicken stations has been a large export of chickens to the old country. People had been talking about that business and the papers had been writing it up and the government had been urging the people to go into it during a number of years, but the people did not go into it in Glengarry until this experimental station was inaugurated.

I have listened to this discussion all evening and naturally expected to find that the government had made some mistakes. But it seems they never make any. Their goods shipped in cold storage arrive in bad condition, but the government is not to blame. They undertook the chicken business and the chickens got sick and died. But still the minister asserts that it has been a very profitable business. The hon. minister proves to the country by his own failures that his administration is a marked success in every respect. I cannot see the logic of it, and it seems to me that if the hon. gentleman would frankly admit his failures, the country would take that admission in the proper spirit. We all know that the work is largely experimental and must expect failure in some instances, but the hon. gentleman has an excuse in every case and makes out that he is infallible. I hardly think he will persuade the country to take this view of his administration. I did not quite understand the hon. gentleman's statement with regard to the cheese-curing stations, but I drew from it that a different kind of cheese is now required, somewhat softer in texture, aud which cannot be cured by the old process. But there can be no doubt that Canadian cheese attained great success many years ago before this process

was thought of, and I would like the hon. gentleman to explain why he suggests the manufacture of a different class of cheese requiring a different treatment from the cheese we made in the past and which met with such success.

For a number of years the English market has been asking for a moistei- and softer cheese than the Canadian Cheddar usually has been. It is impossible to send such cheese successfully forward in heated ships or to cure it successfully in a heated room. For that reason we have been trying to get ventilated holds for the ships to carry it in and to get curing rooms where it can be successfully cured. We have not been able to make that cheese in Canada because v e had not properly constructed cheese factories. We have explained that to the people for three or four years back and have experimented to see whether that kind of cheese could be made in a cooler chamber. Our experiments show that it can be, and that there was nothing 'nherent in the Canadian climate or soii to prevent our making it. By a series of experiments extending over a couple of years, we have been trying to find the caus>' of the difficulty and a remedy for it. And we think that, to a certain extent we are likely to attain the object desired. There is no doubt that the cheese that went forward in the four ships I have referred to arrived in much better condition than others. We have the reports of the receivers, and also resolutions passed by the shippers, and resolutions passed by the produce dealers in London, declaring that they wished all cheese carried in this way. But I do not think the remedy will be complete until the place in which the cheese is to be cured can be kept at a low enough temperature. The ordinary curing room in the country is not of that construction. We have tried for a couple of years to get the people to change their curing rooms, but they have simply ignored the advice. In a few instances they may have adopted it, but so few tn.'.t it has made no impression upon the market. By inaugurating these central curing rooms, we think we may make an impression on the market and induce tne people to adopt the reform.
Is there any idea that the process of making cheese may be changed as well as the process of curing ?
I am not a cheese maker, but I understand that it is expected that, with the new facilities for curing, they will be able to leave a little more moisture in the cheese in the process of manufacture.

I am inclined to think that factory men will not greatly favour putting their cheese into these buildings. It would be more likely that the buyers would do so. I would urge upon the minister Mr. CLANCY.
to consider the propriety of building a larger building at the places where the most cheese is made. Then, if it were near a railway line, so that cartage could be saved, it is possible that the building could be sold without much loss when the experiments are finished.

I may explain that these buildings are to be placed right in the railway yard, where there will be every facility for shipment. The cheese will be brought there from the factories and held for the owners. We do not require it to be sold to anybody. The cheese is as much under the control of the owner as it would be in the factory curing room. The only limitation, if you call it such, is that we cannot allow the cheese to remain indefinitely in the central curing room, for we should choke up these curing rooms and disable ourselves from curing the new cheese coming in. These buildings are not intended for warehouse purposes, but for curing purposes. After the cheese is cured, it must be sold or removed to an ordinary warehouse or cold storage building.
Is the hon. minister sure that green cheese right from the press can be put on a wagon and drawn five miles in safety ?

We believe so-of course, with special arrangements for transportation. And in reply to the hon. member for Middlesex (Mr. Gilmour) I may say that I have been overwhelmed with letters from the factory men asking for the privilege of curing their cheese in these buildings.
If this cheese is to be hauled five miles over a country road, I do not see why it cannot be taken thirty or forty miles by rail.
It is a different thing altogether. A spring wagon does not jolt the cheese anything like the rattling of a railway train.
Is the hon minister making any arrangements for the carrying of the cheese by train from the curing houses ?
No, the owner ships in any way he pleases.
Are there any cars on the different railways suitable for carrying that cheese to the seaboard ?
The cheese would go from these curing rooms just as it goes from the curing rooms in use to-day.

Returning to the subject of imultry. I desire to ask one question. The hon. member for Glengarry (Mr. Schell) has stated that the poultry trade in his county has developed very largely since the introduction of this system of poultry feed-
2C49

ing. But, from the presentation of the case by the hon. member from Leeds (Mr. Taylor) it appears that nearly all the experiments were failures financially. Will the hon. minister explain, if the poultry feeding station under the government was a failure, how an ordinary man commencing the feeding of chickens under the guidance of the government can be expected to make a success of it ?
The stations were not failures financially.
If I understand correctly, in every case they lost money.

I explained that the government carried on at these stations a great deal of educational and experimental work which the farmer would not carry on, and we have to charge up the expense of it to the several stations.
How many of these were in the province of Ontario ?
Four last year I am told.
Where are they located ?
The four last year were at Whitby, Chatham, Holmesville and Renfrew.

I understood that one of these stations at Lancaster was not successful because of an epidemic disease. Is that a thing that happens frequently, and what is the reason for it, and what is done on the discovery of it ?
We had about ten stations and this is the only one at which it occurred.

The minister says that the reason the fattening station cost the government more than it would have cost a private individual was the educational work they had to do. I would ask the minister what amount of educational work was done at the Sussex station which was in charge of this agricultural implement agent, and what qualifications he had for imparting this information ? I would like to know also what education he gave the people ?

His work was not a failure so far as the fattening of chickens was concerned. But besides this work the people who came to learn from these experiments had to be shown what was being done, that took time, and the time had to be paid for.

I understand that the ground the minister takes is that because the chickens were sold for more than was paid for them, therefore there was a profit. They cost, I believe, $85 and were sold for $117. But there were other expenses of over $200. Because the chickens were sold
for more than they cost, the minister claims the experiment was a financial success.
Without going into details, I am informed that the original cost of the chickens bought and the feed given to them was about two-thirds of what they brought.

The report that was read by the hon. member for Leeds does not bear out the contention of the minister. All these items, with the exception of a few of the crates, were the same sort of items that would have to be paid for by any private individual engaged in the same enterprise. I cannot understand how it can be, as the hon. member for Glengarry said, that on account of the success of this experiment in Glengarry where it was a dead failure and the chickens died, it encouraged the people of that community to go into this enterprise as a private speculation.
The MINISTER OF AGRICUT/*''	'
It is a kind of encouragement that brings them money.
I have heard it said the chickens died owing to the way they were fed. Has the department discovered by this time if that is the case ?
I am not able to answer that question.
I have been told they were fed on buttermilk, and it caused the liver to grow'.
I do not think they w'ere fed on buttermilk. We did not make any such experiments.
Were the chickens who died of this chickenpox examined by veterinarians ?

I do not think they were.
Hon. Mr. ROSS (Victoria, N.S.) I think, to remove all doubts, W'e should issue a commission to go down to Glengarry and ascertain the cause of these chickens dying. But speaking seriously, this business of feeding and shipping chickens is now in its initial stage. Some parties have been successful, and others have not. But people are getting better acquainted with it, and if you allow this process to go on you will find that next year and the year following the export of chickens will keep on increasing in value. One man may try the business and fail, and another may try and succeed. That is the way in every business because if every man succeeded we would all be so rich that the country could not contain us.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: The minister will persist in making a statement to this House that the business has been profitable, and he answers my hon. friend here that the cost

Of course the milk requires to be in good condition. I am glad to say that in Canada there is practically no skim milk cheese made, nor is there any skimming of the milk at the factories. That matter has been thoroughly gone into by our dairy officers. We have our inspectors, and the cheese-makers themselves look after the quality of the milk.

Would not the milk suffer from being drawn a long distance to the factory ?
Now, Sir. Sainsburg may have been a farmer, and there is not an item there that any farmer would not have to pav for in the chicken business. There is nothing there for experimental work or instruction to the farmer. The chickens were shipped and sold, and there is $10 return, leaving a deficiency of $237. Now, did these chickens die ? There is the published statement of the hon. gentleman. I simply read the items that he furnishes the department of the Auditor General, including the expenditure for chickens and their feed, boxes to ship them in, and freight, that any other farmer would have to pay. Besides, he allowed his political friends where he established the station, some pay for looking after them. But the experimental work was done by the department the same as in Glengarry. At Bondville, Que., there was a loss of $239; at Charlottetown, a loss of $105; at Sussex, N.B., a loss of $198, and at Chatham, of $237 ; and so it goes.
Is it the intention of the minister to establish more of these fattening stations the coming year, and at what points ?
We will have more stations going on this year, I cannot say yet the exact points, and some will be continued where they are.
Has the minister made up his mind which ones will be continued, whether it will be the most successful or the least successful ?
I think they have all been so successful as to justify me in continuing them.

As the discussion has been carried on with respect to chickens and cheese, I would ask the minister if he has given any attention to the supervision of the milk carried to the factories, so as to secure its being of a proper quality ? It needs a good quality of milk to make a good cheese for export. Has he taken Mr. TAYLOR.
The milk will be drawn to the factory in the future as it has been in the past. It does sometimes suffer from being carried too long a distance.
Are the manufacturers confined to certain weights of cheese for shipment, or can they make a cheese of any weight they please ?
They can make it of any weight.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: The minister did not give me information in reference to the great discrepancy in the case at Chatham, where there was a deficiency of $237.63.
I cannot explain those figures. No doubt a full explanation can be made in the department.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Will the hon. gentleman get it ?
I have given a full statement of the expenses.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: The minister savs that with the exception of the station at Lancaster all the others paid a profit. Now, the chickens that were sold from this station brought $16.09, and he paid out $253.72 to Mr. Sainsburg. A cyclone must - have struck those chickens up there. That is worse than a disease.
As to the milk, I understood the hon. minister to state that a certain test is required. What is that test ?

I do not think that I said anything particularly about that. I do not know whether the hon. gentleman is alluding to the ordinary working of cheese factories or not. There is no change in the method of handling milk in the cheese factory. That system has been pursued for many years. ' It

is thoroughly understood and we do not propose to make any change in that at all.

After having had a fair share of chickens and cheese I wish to go back to apples again. I would like to ask the hon. minister if he has arranged for the appointment of a man to do grafting and pruning in Prince Edward Island, and to assist the orchardist there ? I understand that a gentleman down there, Mr. D. A. Sharp, has applied for this position. The hon. minister will remember that a few years ago he sent a man of the name of Ivinsman from Nova Scotia to Prince Edward Island who was totally unfit to carry on this work and made a failure of it. I understand that there is a largely signed petition in the department of the hon. minister asking that Mr. Sharp be appointed to do the work of pruning and grafting. Mr. Sharp is a Liberal, a personal friend of mine, though a strong political opponent, but he has beeu in the nursery business for a long number of years, and he is thoroughly conversant with the cultivation of fruit trees. In view of the fact that the hon. minister has a memorial in his hands signed by a large proportion of the people engaged in that industry in Prince Edward Island, I hope he will pay some attention to it. We do not want to have a repetition of Kinsman coming over there from Nova Scotia. Mr. Sharp is a nurseryman who has been selling his trees to the farmers of Prince Edward Island for a long number of years. I think he represents a' nursery situated somewhere in the vicinity of Sussex, and he deals in trees that are suitable for Prince Edward Island. He has taken a deep interest in the cultivation of these trees. He goes around as far as he possibly can, being a man who is dependent for his living on the work he is doing, assisting the parties to whom he has sold trees in the cultivation of them. But he cannot give his whole time and attention to that without some compensation from the government and I would, therefore, as far as I can in this parliament, make known the capabilities of Mr. Sharpe and his thorough knowledge of and acquaintance with orchard work in Prince Edward Island. I would like to ask the hon. minister, having this memorial signed by a large number of the people of Prince Edward Island, that he would be good enough to pay some attention to it.

I would like to ask the hon. minister what his practice is in respect to giving bonuses to storehouses where butter is kept in cold storage by creamery companies, on what principle he gives these bonuses and what the initial value of the buildings is to which these bonuses are given V

The buildings in connection with the creameries which earn these bonuses have to bo constructed according to specifications and
plans which are supplied by the department, which have been published for years, which have been explained before the committee and drawings of which were put before the country in bulletins three or four years ago. The bonus as given is $50 for the first year and $25 for two succeeding years on the condition that the buildings themselves are properly constructed, and that the temperature is kept at the right point during the hot weather. We require first of all that an inspector shall visit the creamery and see whether the building is all right, and if it is we get a report from the butter maker there who fills up the form which is sent by the department. When that is done wre pay the bonus.
Then application is made for this bonus ?
Yes. Made by the creameries and then we supply all the information necessary as to construction and forms for making reports upon.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Who inspects these buildings ?	[DOT]
The officers of the department.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: In every case ?
What is the average cost of these buildings ?

That would depend on whether they are built inside of an existing creamery or outside. It costs about $150, Professor Robertson says, to fit up the inside of a building, but when an additional building has to be built it will probably cost $250 or $300. The government gives $100 in the course of three years, $50 the first year and $25 for two succeeding years.
How many creameries have earned that bonus ?
About 500-not the full bonus; some of them are still earning their bonuses, but about 500 have put in the cold storage chambers. Some of them will come on next year or the year after.
How many of them have earned the full $100 ?
About 330, Professor Robertson says, have earned the full bonus.
I notice in this pamphlet, containing figures which have come from the department, the number is placed at 317 that have earned the full $100 up to 1900.
That will be about it.
How many does the hon. minister say now have earned the full $100 ?
I aru only speaking from memory, but I understand about 330. If it was 317 then it must be more now.
How many applications have been made from New Brunswick for this bonus ?
Professor Robertson thinks about six. There are not very many creameries in New Brunswick.

paid out to different parties in the province of Quebec and for $22 paid out to parties in Ontario for inspecting cold storage rooms. I see here T. Corbeil Laurentides, 21 days at $2 a day, inspections for bonuses, and so it runs on.

Yes.

Yes.

speechtext: Then I asked him if these inspections were made by an officer of the department from here, and he said yes.
The hon. gentleman did not ask if he was from here. He is an officer of the department. He is one of the syndicate inspectors for Quebec, and we asked him to do that work.

speechtext: Then there is J. O. Danis?

I do not recognize the name.
Mi-. TAYLOR. You will find it in the Auditor General's report, page D-64.
I dare say, but I cannot recognize the name.

He is one of the Ontario inspectors that we employed for that work.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Then there is A. B. Rabb. of Brockville, who got $2 a day ?
I do not know any one of that name.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: These are not officers of the department but there is $485 paid to about thirty inspectors in the province of Quebec and $22 paid to six in Ontario.

They were employed for that purpose.
Mr. TA i LOR. The minister led us to believe that before this money was paid out an officer of the department certified that these places were completed according to law. Here we find that they are not ins-spected by an officer of the department at all.
Wherever it was possible the work was done by an officer of the department and in every other case it was done by a person engaged in similar work for some provincial or local organization.
Have you one of those cold storage places at Charlottetown.
We engaged a room in a cold storage building there.
And the buyer of the cheese pays a rent for the use of this building during the time the cheese is there.
He pays a storage charge.

You are building one of those cheese curing establishments in Eastern Ontario, another in Western Ontario ; one in French Quebec and one in English Quebec. Why in the name of all that is good and gracious cannot you build one in Prince Edward Island, where the people have gone largely into the cheese industry ow'ing to the energy of Prof. Robertson and prior to this government coming into power. Prof. Robertson came down to Prince Edward Island under the Conservative government and established these cheese factories, and they have been a great success. The cheese industry lias been a success there without any assistance from this government, only that they rented this cold storage room from the Rattenburys, friends of their own in Charlottetown. The least the government ought to do is to build one of those cheese curing establishments in Prince Edward Island. The minister tells us that when the cheese is treated in one of those places it will come out perfect and be worth from three to four cents a pound more than ordinary cheese. Why should not the people of every province have the benefit of them. Why build two in Ontario and two in Quebec and not build any in New Brunswick. Nova Scotia. Prince Edward Island and Manitoba. We should have in the province of Erince Edward Island this means of turning the dairy products of the people to ' the best advantage. I trust the minister

will see his way clear to establish one of these places in Prince Edward Island.
To promote dairying interests by advances for milk and cream, to be recouped out of the proceeds of sales of such butter and cheese, to be placed to the credit of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, $40,000.

What has been the outcome of the partnership business with the government in respect to the North-west creameries. As was predicted by some gentlemen here when the minister first submitted the plan, it has resulted in a loss, 1 and I think the minister told us that he was disposed to discontinue the assistance. How far has he been successful in recouping that loss.
The hon. gentleman is correct in saying that some of these factories have not been as successful/ as we had anticipated. The late boom in grain-growing-
Another excuse.

Yes, another excuse ; possibly a mistake in placing some of these factories in the graingrowing region. We have discontinued one or two, and I fear that we will have to discontinue some others. We have lent altogether $43,540.63. Of that $24,528.87 has been repaid at present, leaving a balance of $19,011. Eight of these factories out of twenty-one have repaid the whole of the advances, four others have paid very nearly all, and I am certain will entirely repay next season if there is anything like the work that has been done lately. There are a few which I fear will lose money. These are, Edmonton and its tributaries, Maple Creek, Prince Albert and Duck Lake, and Wolseley and Moffat. The others owe much smaller amounts and it is likely they will be able to pay off. After all that is not a bad showing although I confess that the anticipations have not been realized as far as the actual financial view is concerned.
I think, however, that the progress of the country there has been benefited to an enormous extent, and that the encouragement to settlers on the whole is quite good compensation for the investment which was made, even if in some instances we lost.
Has the minister discontinued the assistance.

I hope to be able in another year to let those who have repaid the whole amount, run their own business without any control from us. Some of the others will have to be run for a year or two perhaps to ensure tlie successful paying off of what is due. With regard to some others it is rather a blue lookout. This is very similar to the work done in Prince Edward Island some years ago, but on a smaller scale.
What creameries have" paid up ?

Churchbridge, Kootenay, Grenville, Moose Jaw, Red Deer, Regina, Saltcoats, Saskatoon, Whitewood, Yorktown. These? owe nothing. Four of the others have nearly paid off everything, and seven have not paid much.
Has the one at Calgary paid off its debt ?
At Calgary the money was not lent to the corporation, but to the patrons, and they have paid it off.
What is the output of the whole of the creameries ?

In 1897, 473,000 pounds of butter were made, value $85,000. In 1898, 484,000 pounds value $73,000; in 1899, 501,000 pounds, value $103,000; in 1900,	637,000 pounds, value
$128,000; in 1901,	677,000 pounds, value
$129,000. There has been a steady increase both in quantity and value.
Does the hon. minister control the sale ?

We manage the sale. Most of it was marketed in British Columbia and the Yukon, but this last season we shipped some to Europe. Some has been sent every year to Japan-not a very large quantity, but gradually increasing.
I am surprised that any should be required. I thought that the Yukon would have taken the 'whole of it.

That is due to the fact that a great deal of Manitoba butter was sent to British Columbia this year and some Ontario and Quebec butter. In the early spring there was some sent from the east.
